data.title: 65 Greatest Christmas Songs of All Time, Ranked
data.meta_description: From Motown classics to indie-pop anthems, these are the best modern Christmas songs for your playlist.
data.text:
Love them, hate them, or just accept them as a sort of immutable fact of life, it's officially Christmas song season in 2023. And although thereâ€™s been a fair amount of disposable novelty rubbish written over the years, the reality is that a lot of Christmas songs are bangers.

There are plenty of keepers from the â€˜40s-â€˜70s heyday of the Christmas record as an art form, for example, but even more cynical later generations of pop have produced plenty of gold. Festive cheer has found its way into pop, hip-hop, R&B, metal, punk, indieâ€¦ you name it. So as a gift, we've rounded up the very best Christmas songs going. Ho ho ho.

1. â€˜All I Want For Christmas Is Youâ€™ by Mariah Carey

Itâ€™s hard to believe, but there was a time when Mimiâ€™s inescapable ear worm was just a forgotten novelty song from yet another standard-issue pop-singer holiday album. Now, in a post Love Actually world, hearing â€˜All I Want For Christmas Is Youâ€™ for the first time in a year is one of the most reliable signs that the holidays are here. The song came and went when released in 1995, but snowballed in cultural cachet in the aughts, slowly climbing in popularity every year before finally topping US charts in 2019 and the UK charts in 2020. Complaining about its ubiquity has become a pastime for killjoys at pubs, but itâ€™s their loss: From the twinkly intro to Mariahâ€™s tour-de-force delivery, everything here is as timeless as it is flawless.

2. â€˜Fairytale of New Yorkâ€™ by The Pogues and Kirsty MacColl

When was the last time you properly listened to Kirsty MacColl and The Poguesâ€™ epic Big Apple-set fable? Shut your eyes and give it a go, and if you arenâ€™t a nervous wreck by the fade-out, your heart (like that jumper from your nan) is two sizes too small. â€˜Fairytaleâ€¦â€™ is a perfect four-minute narrative of hope, despair and heartbreak â€“ and, despite the profanity, it ends with love.

James Manning

Content Director, EMEA

Advertising

3. â€˜Last Christmasâ€™ by Wham!

A ballad of doomed romance, â€˜Last Christmasâ€™ features sleighbells and synths, plus some truly memorable knitwear in the video. But what really sets â€˜Last Christmasâ€™ apart is George Michaelâ€™s heart-on-sleeve delivery: his genuine heartbreak horror (â€˜My God! I thought you were someone to rely onâ€™) and wistful, sexy whispers. The words â€˜Merry Christmasâ€™ never sounded so sultry.

4. â€˜White Christmasâ€™ by Bing Crosby

The power of Christmas nostalgia itself is greater than real memories. Hence, all of us can hark back with Bing on this Irving Berlin-penned â€™40s number to a white Christmas just like the ones we used to know, even if our true past is full of crushing disappointments (December 25, 1993 â€“ no Hornby train set).

Advertising

5. â€˜Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)â€™ by Darlene Love

Is this the most moving Christmas tune of all time? Probably â€“ the combination of Darlene Loveâ€™s impeccable pleading vocal, Phil Spectorâ€™s gloriously tinselly production and Ellie Greenwich and Jeff Barryâ€™s magical songwriting could make anyone, even the biggest Scrooge, melt like a snowman under a hairdryer. Itâ€™s just an absolutely perfect Christmas song.

6. Feliz Navidad by JosÃ© Feliciano

Feliz Navidad is a criminally underrated Christmas song, despite apparently being one of the most played across the world. Itâ€™s been around for years and years, originally released way back in 1970, but its jaunty, cheerful energy has stood the test of time. The trumpets, the classic well-wishes belted in Spanish, the strum of the Puerto Rican cuatro? What a catchy, merry treat. Whack it on your christmas playlists â€“ itâ€™ll really spread the joy.

Advertising

7. â€˜Baby, It's Cold Outsideâ€™ By Ella Fitzgerald and Louis Armstrong

Queen Ella Fitzgerald and King Louis Armstrong are a completely necessary part of every Christmas, IMO. They actually have a whole Christmas album together, but â€˜Baby, Itâ€™s Cold Outsideâ€™ is the absolute classic from their repertoire. A twinkling piano and a double bass are all thatâ€™s needed for their soft, mellow harmonies, but wack the whole album on and youâ€™ve got the perfect soundtrack to your Christmas nibbles and cocktails evening.

8. â€˜Santa Claus is Coming to Townâ€™ by the Jackson 5

There are versions of this song by everyone from Bieber to BublÃ©, but Michael and the gangâ€™s effort is the grooviest and the most fun. And since the song is mainly used as a bargaining tool by parents, it does make sense to have kids on the mic.

Advertising

9. â€˜Stay Another Dayâ€™ by East 17

East 17â€™s all-time Christmas classic wasnâ€™t supposed to be a Christmas song at all. As the Walthamstow, England groupâ€™s songwriting member Tony Mortimer told us recently, itâ€™s actually an incredibly sad song inspired by his brotherâ€™s suicide. That raw emotion seems to seep into the groupâ€™s gorgeously sombre four-part harmonies and even the inevitable Christmas song sleigh bells, producing a peerless exercise in festive melancholy.

10. â€˜Childâ€™s Christmas in Walesâ€™ by John Cale

Didnâ€™t Christmas feel so much simpler as a child? That notion underpins John Caleâ€™s â€˜Childâ€™s Christmas in Walesâ€™, a tune inspired by a prose piece by Welsh poet Dylan Thomas that is similarly stream-of-conscious and likewise overspills with nostalgia. But even without the lyrics youâ€™d fully guess this was a festive one. With its jolly pace, swooning guitar, serene verses and twinkling organ solo, â€˜Childâ€™s Christmas in Walesâ€™ is an alternative Crimbo tune, but a Crimbo tune nonetheless.

Ed Cunningham

News Editor, Time Out UK and Time Out London

Advertising

11. â€˜Rockinâ€™ Around the Christmas Treeâ€™ by Brenda Lee

Being Jewish, songwriter Johnny Marks didnâ€™t celebrate Christmas, but in the â€™40s and â€™50s he wrote some of the greatest Christmas songs of all time. Among them are â€˜Rudolph, The Red-Nosed Reindeer,â€™ â€˜I Heard The Bells of Christmas Day,â€™ and this â€“ an easy-on-the-ear rock â€™nâ€™ roll tune sung by a 13-year-old Brenda Lee, which really needs no introduction.

12. â€˜Wonderful Christmas Timeâ€™ by Paul McCartney

Good old Macca. Whereas Lennon could be relied upon to make impressive political statements (when he wasn't laying about in bed all day), McCartney is the master of the charmingly naÃ¯ve pop opus. This little ditty â€” which is essnetially Paul goofing around on a synth â€” isn't going to shake up your festive paradigm, but it won't half stick in your head.

Advertising

13. â€˜Driving Home for Christmasâ€™ by Chris Rea

This loungey number about being stuck in Christmas traffic from husky-voiced housewivesâ€™ favourite Chris Rea has had surprisingly lasting appeal. Not only has it charted twice in the UK (reaching 53 in 1988 and 33 in 2007) but it even cracked Norwayâ€™s Top Three a few years ago. Clearly people of all generations and nationalities are able to enjoy this harmless slice of Christmas cheese.

14. â€˜Christmas Rappin'â€™ by Kurtis Blow

At the beginning of this somewhat unlikely 1980 Christmas smash, you can hear the moment at which hip hop arrived. Interrupting a starchy recital of â€˜A Visit from St Nicholas,â€™ Kurtis Blow launches into his own inner city yarn about Santa showing up to a Harlem Christmas party, producing a Yuletide classic â€“ and rapâ€™s first major-label hit.

James Manning

Content Director, EMEA

Advertising

15. â€˜Sleigh Rideâ€™ by The Ronettes

Ronnie Spectorâ€™s distinctive and sensual vocals could easily melt any Christmas snow. On this highlight from the classic Phil Spector Christmas album, she purrs about getting cosy under a blanket on a sleigh ride while her fellow Ronettes â€˜ring-a-ling-a-ling-a-ding-dong-dingâ€™ in the background. Spectorâ€™s arrangement may be full of trilling bells and clip-clopping hooves, but the melodyâ€™s irrepressible warmth hints at the fact that this song was composed (by light orchestral maestro Leroy Anderson) during a July heatwave.

16. â€˜8 Days of Christmasâ€™ by Destinyâ€™s Child

Thereâ€™s nothing quite like when the slow, warbling Christmas classics have been playing all day and someone wacks on this chaotic 2001 banger by Destinyâ€™s Child. Itâ€™s essentially an unnervingly fast-paced version of â€˜12 Days of Christmasâ€™, but instead of five golden rings, the ladies get back rubs, cropped denim jackets and Chloe shades. Oh, and â€˜a gift certificate to buy my favourite CDs.â€™ Itâ€™s painfully noughties and itâ€™s so bad, itâ€™s good. Say it with me, â€˜doesnâ€™t it feel like Christmas?â€™

Advertising

17. â€˜Frosty the Snowmanâ€™ by Cocteau Twins

The 1950 classic gets an early-â€™90s ethereal keyboard treatment courtesy of Scottish dreamers the Cocteau Twins. Singer Elizabeth Fraser could have plumbed the aching sadness of snowman existence but instead her vocals are all shimmering colours and dancing forest fairies. When the overlapping harmonies come in around 1:36 you know that this Christmas is going to be pretty magical.

18. â€˜Jingle Bell Rockâ€™ by Bobby Helms

Following its release in 1957, this rockabilly ditty topped the Christmas charts five years in a row, making it a veritable holiday classic even by the early â€™60s. Today it retains a towering presence in the Christmas canon, as synonymous with the holiday as tinsel and paper crowns.

Advertising

19. â€˜Happy Xmas (War Is Over)â€™ by John Lennon & Yoko Ono

John Lennon and Yoko Onoâ€™s definitive festive peace-on-earth song is an inescapable feature of every Christmas, transcending its original anti-Vietnam War purpose to become a one-size-fits-all Christmas banger. Sure, bits of it make you cringe. But that's all part of the season, eh?

20. â€˜I Wish It Could Be Christmas Everydayâ€™ by Wizzard

You could just listen to this perfect slice of pure â€™70s pop, from the tongue-in-cheek â€˜ker-chingâ€™ of a ringing till to the fade-out of a childrenâ€™s choir and twinkling bells. You could do that. Or take the plunge into the strange acid trip of Wizzard live and witness Roy Woodâ€™s haunted eyes set in a face dripping with snowy glitter. Scary Christmas.

Advertising

21. â€˜Step Into Christmasâ€™ by Elton John

Sir Elton annonces â€˜welcome to my Christmas songâ€™ at the top of this piano-driven banger, signaling to us all that this is a Christmas song with zero alterior motives except to become a yuletide classic. Mission accomplished.

22. â€˜Merry Christmas Babyâ€™ by Ike and Tina Turner

Tina howls and growls her way through Christmas, R&B style, and tops it all off with a spirited freestyle nod to â€˜Jingle Bellsâ€™ for good measure.

Advertising

23. â€˜Christmas Wrappingâ€™ by The Waitresses

If you love new wave bands like Blondie and Talking Heads, this is surely the Christmas song for you. It begins cynically with singer Patty Donahue declaring â€˜I think Iâ€™ll miss this one this year,â€™ before an unexpected romance blossoms in the closing stages and warms her jaded cockles. As festive tunes go, this oneâ€™s as dry and delicious as champagne paid for by your boss.

24. â€˜Christmas in Hollisâ€™ by Run-DMC

Certainly the most well-known Christmas hip hop tunes and one of the best, too, Run DMCâ€™s witty Crimbo tale is the story of Run finding Santaâ€™s bill-stuffed wallet in the park on Christmas Eve. â€˜But I'd never steal from Santa, cause that ainâ€™t right,â€™ says Run, in a fine show of festive spirit. It all makes for an ultimately catchy number that provides you with a bit of bounce if youâ€™re feeling flat after too much Slade and Macca, or just too many mince pies.

Advertising

25. â€˜Do They Know Itâ€™s Christmas?â€™ by Band Aid

Bob Geldof and Midge Ureâ€™s 1984 reaction to the Ethiopian famine, with contributions from Phil Collins, Sting, Macca and Bono, was a publicity machine of epic proportions. It worked: â€˜Do They Know Itâ€™s Christmas?â€™ stayed at the top spot for five weeks, and was the biggest UK chart success of the decade. Put that all aside, and itâ€™s also just a great (and surprisingly unconventional) pop song, meteorological misunderstandings about snow be damned.

26. â€˜Blue Christmasâ€™ by Elvis Presley

The King adds some characteristic swagger to this cover of the 1948 country original. Spawning plenty of tributes of its own, Presley sealed the deal for â€˜Blue Christmasâ€™ â€“ itâ€™s now a festive staple.

Advertising

27. â€˜Santa Tell Meâ€™ by Ariana Grande

Ari didnâ€™t score a Mariah-level megahit with this peppy, upbeat ode to joy, but she came closer than almost any other pop star in the 30-ish years since â€˜All I Want for Christmas Is You.â€™ Unlike Kelly Clarkson â€“ who scored a memorable hit by channeling Darlene Love â€“ Ariâ€™s song fits right in her catalog of bopsâ€¦ meaning you can comfortably transition between this plea to St. Nick and her recent hit about a late-night tantra session with relative ease.

28. â€˜Santa Claus Go Straight to the Ghettoâ€™ by James Brown

The godfather of funk gives Father Christmas his marching orders, insisting he head straight to the ghetto and â€˜tell â€˜em James Brown sent ya.â€™ It may raise a smile, thereâ€™s something serious at the heart of this all-horns-blazing tune: JB wants the kids on the wrong side of the tracks to enjoy the sort of Christmas he never did.

Advertising

29. â€˜Run Rudolph Runâ€™ by Chuck Berry

Recorded at the height of his powers, Chuck Berry rolls out his characteristic frenzied 12-bar blues in reverence of everyoneâ€™s favourite reindeer. Despite not even managing to break the top 50 when it was first released, it has become an enduring holiday favourite and spawned plenty of covers.

30. â€˜O Tannenbaumâ€™ by Vince Guaraldi Trio

A bit like the Frasier theme tune, itâ€™s impossible to listen to this version of â€˜O Tannenbaumâ€™ (from the soundtrack to A Charlie Brown Christmas) without doing the classic jazz lean-and-nod. Basically, press play and youâ€™re suddenly cooler. This could be a good one to change up the vibe from Christmas lazing to some Christmas loving.

Advertising

31. â€˜8 Days of Christmasâ€™ by Destinyâ€˜s Child

With an injection of sass and unabashed materialism, BeyoncÃ©, Kelly and Michelle turned a cosy old holiday favourite into a bumping R&B Christmas carol for our times. A fine achievement.

32. â€˜Peace on Earth/The Little Drummer Boyâ€™ by Bing Crosby and David Bowie

This surreal encounter on Bing Crosbyâ€™s 42nd Christmas Special between The Thin White Duke and the good olâ€™ boy of American family TV has become the stuff of legend. After Dave mistakes Bing for a butler and Bing jibes at Bowieâ€™s music taste, they launch into a medley of â€˜The Little Drummer Boyâ€™ and â€˜Peace On Earth.â€™ The results are... astounding.

Advertising

33. â€˜Zat You, Santa Claus?â€™ by Louis Armstrong

Despite the fact itâ€™s recorded by one of the greatest jazz musicians ever to walk the planet, this Crimbo song keeps a surprisingly low profile when the Xmas tunes are rolled out. It didnâ€™t make too much of a splash for Louis, either, but you know what? Itâ€™s him having fun, as shown by the jolly, cheeky lyrics and jumpy trumpet lines that fuel the song. And when it comes down to it, Christmas should be fun. Good on you, Louis, letâ€™s hope that Santa does indeed slip that pleasantly pleasant present under your door, as requested.

34. â€˜Underneath the Treeâ€™ by Kelly Clarkson

Sure, Kelly Clarksonâ€™s foray into festive music is kind of a shameless attempt to write a new â€˜All I Want for Christmas Is Youâ€™ smashed together with Darlene Loveâ€™s â€˜Christmas (Baby Please Come Home),â€™ but it gets away with it. Why? Partly because the songwriting offers just the right blend of schmaltz and Spector-style sass, but also because Clarksonâ€™s superb vocal performance radiates a sincerity thatâ€™s completely infectious. Oh, and her high note towards the end is a moment.

Advertising

35. â€˜Father Christmasâ€™ by The Kinks

In the particularly rollicking, punk-adjacent riot, Ray Davies not only spoils Santaâ€™s true identity, he also threatens to kick his ass if he doesnâ€™t give him some money. At its heart, itâ€™s a sad song about poor kidsâ€™ disappointment on Christmas. Itâ€™s also a hilarious, snotty, overlooked piece of Christmas counter-programming from one of rockâ€™s all time greats.

36. â€˜O Come, O Come, Emmanuelâ€™ by Sufjan Stevens

No one does Christmas quite like our Sufjan. Not content with releasing a 42-track Songs For Christmas album in 1996, this year he put out Silver & Gold â€“ a whopping 101-song collection celebrating Jesusâ€™s birthday. Picking a favourite out of his festive back catalogue is tough, but we rate â€˜O Come O Come Emmanuelâ€™ â€“ a reworking of the traditional favourite on â€˜Songs For Christmasâ€™ â€“ as our favourite track. Sparse and haunting, but also uplifting, itâ€™s a beautiful little call to rejoice.

Advertising

37. â€˜Rockinâ€™ Around the Christmas Treeâ€™ by Brenda Lee

Another all-time festive standard that somewhat counterintuitively emerged from the largely disposable, transient rockabilly craze of the â€™50s. Thirteen at the time, singer Brenda Lee has stated that she has no idea why songwriter Johnny Marks was so keen she be the one to tackle this song. But well over 60 years later and it remains a sweet, sprightly classic, the epitome of unjaded excitement about the holidays as Lee yelps away about her excitement at having a seasonal boogie.

38. â€˜Riverâ€™ by Joni Mitchell

Think you had a bad Christmas last year when you burned the turkey? Spare a thought for Joni Mitchell, whoâ€™s heartbroken and wants to escape the Xmas merriment all around her. From the â€˜Jingle Bellsâ€™-drenched-in-melancholy piano opening, itâ€™s clear this isnâ€™t going to be a jolly ride, but itâ€™s still beautiful and delicate. By the end, all youâ€™ll want to do is skate away with Joni (her oft-repeated cry throughout the song) and help mend her broken heart. Perhaps thatâ€™s why itâ€™s one of her most covered songs, having been recorded by over 500 people.

Advertising

39. â€˜Dear Santa (Bring Me a Man This Christmas)â€™ by The Weather Girls

Itâ€™s not just a drizzle of dudes that gets The Weather Girls going. From the same album as â€˜Itâ€™s Raining Menâ€™ (and pulling all the same moves with a festive twist), â€˜Dear Santaâ€™ is a seasonal stormer that represents the grooviest Christmas list ever written. Bonus points for the â€˜fa-la-la-la-laâ€™ backing vocals.

40. â€˜2000 Milesâ€™ by The Pretenders

It sounds like a take on the classic â€˜itâ€™s Christmas, I miss youâ€™ theme, but Chrissie Hyndeâ€™s frosty ballad gets much sadder when you know it was written for the bandâ€™s guitarist James Honeyman-Scott, who had died the previous year. Honeyman-Scottâ€™s replacement Robbie McIntosh pays tribute with some gorgeous arpeggios: the closest a guitar gets to the sound of snowfall.

James Manning

Content Director, EMEA

Advertising

41. â€˜In Dulci Jubiloâ€™ by Mike Oldfield

If you needed any more proof that the â€™70s were a weird, weird time, consider this: one of the decadeâ€™s most popular and enduring Christmas hits is a prog-folk version of a JS Bach setting of a carol dating back to the fourteenth century. Sometimes the old tunes are the best.

42. â€˜Glitteryâ€™ by Kacey Musgraves

The alt-country icon managed a minor miracle by turning the abysmal spoiled-brat anthem â€˜I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmasâ€™ into something listenable, but she also managed to carve out a place on the yule playlist with this stripped-down slice of sweetness from her holiday special. Itâ€™s a Christmas love song dripping in cute, and an expertly crafted slow-dance amid all the sleigh bells.

Advertising

43. â€˜Christmas in Harlemâ€™ by Kanye West featuring Camâ€™ron, Jim Jones, Vado, Cyhi Da Prynce & Pusha T

This GOOD Music Christmas posse track serves up just about everything youâ€™d expect from Kanye and Ko (except massive delays). A pre-gospel-phase 'Ye raps about unwrapping (removing the knickers from) his Christmas present, Jim Jones proposes we party till dawn and Big Sean saysâ€¦ well, not much at all. But with a slick soul-sampling beat from Hit Boy and bags of braggadocious charm, this is a head-bobbing holiday treat.

44. â€˜Just Like Christmasâ€™ by Low

Crammed full of sleigh bells and lyrically sparse it may be, but somehow indie rockers Low managed to do the unthinkable in 1999: create a genuinely cool Christmas song. â€˜Just Like Christmasâ€™ is a wistful, lo-fi, modern Christmas anthem.

Advertising

45. â€˜Merry Xmas Everybodyâ€™ by Slade

Noddy Holder and his troupe of platform-wearers continue to blight our television screens each December with their frightening fashion sense. Thereâ€™s a reason for that, of course. Itâ€™s the joyful simplicity of 1973â€™s â€˜Merry Xmas Everybody,â€™ which is guaranteed to inject that euphoric, slightly drunken, Christmas-love vibe into the festive season.

46. â€˜Christmas will Break Your Heartâ€™ by LCD Soundsystem

Whatever you think about LCD Soundsystemâ€™s laughably brief retirement, thereâ€™s something pretty rad about James Murphy and flunkies marking their 2015 return via the medium of a low-key, slow-burning Christmas song. â€˜Christmas will Break Your Heartâ€™ starts out almost exactly as depressing as it sounds, but it builds really beautifully via its poignant â€˜but still I'm coming home to youâ€™ and its expansive wall of sound finish. A genuinely lovely record.

Andrzej Lukowski

Theatre & Dance Editor, UK

Advertising

47. â€˜Santa Claus is Sometimes Brownâ€™

Robert Lopez of LA punk outfit The Zeroes wears his El Vez persona like a glove, and his Merry MeX-Mas album is chock full of classics in the waiting, from the honky-tonk â€˜Orange for Christmasâ€™ to his semi-cover â€˜Brown Christmas.â€™ But on â€˜Santa Claus is Sometimes Brown,â€™ he filters the Kingâ€™s pur through a glass of tequila for a sultry blues explosion of come-hither holiday charm.

48. â€˜What Christmas Means to Meâ€™ by Stevie Wonder

If you canâ€™t be bothered to listen and find out, it turns out that singing carols, decorating the tree and, of course, being with his baby is what Christmas means to Stevie. Give it a listen anyway, though, because with that irresistible Motown swing and a harmonica solo thrown in this is (ahem) a cracker.

Advertising

49. â€˜Maryâ€™s Boy Childâ€™ by Harry Belafonte

Trivia fans take note: this is the only song ever to hit Christmas Number One twice, for two totally different artists. â€˜Maryâ€™s Boy Childâ€™ was recorded first by American calypso star Harry Belafonte in 1956. His slow-and-steady, ultra-classy arrangement was a massive hit and it still delivers the Christmas magic 65 years later. Youâ€™ll have to wait and see whether Boney Mâ€™s 1978 disco version can do the same.

James Manning

Content Director, EMEA

50. â€˜What Will Santa Claus Say (When He Finds Everybody Swinging)â€™ by Louis Prima

Given his penchant for kissing mommy under the mistletoe, weâ€™d imagine Santa'd be more than down for a little group love, honestly (yeah, yeah, we know it's not that kind of party). Jazz legend Prima's jaunty sing-along is so catchy that it even gives us a bonus track: Kanye and Kid Kudi sample â€˜What Will Santa Claus Sayâ€™ as the backbone of â€˜4th Dimension,â€™ their haunting collaborative hit as Kids See Ghosts.

Advertising

51. â€˜The Power of Loveâ€™ by Frankie Goes to Hollywood

Like East 17â€™s â€˜Stay Another Dayâ€™, or the film â€˜Die Hardâ€™, Frankie Goes To Hollywoodâ€™s â€˜The Power of Loveâ€™ isnâ€™t about Christmas per se, but is nonetheless inextricably linked to the season of good cheer. Not by accident, either: the video actually features the Nativity of Jesus, a gesture of towering earnestness clearly intended as a somewhat ironic response to the Liverpudlian provocateursâ€™ scandalous early videos. But the song has a powerful, spiritual sincerity that would probably preserve it as a classic even without the visuals.

Andrzej Lukowski

Theatre & Dance Editor, UK

52. â€˜â€™tis the damn seasonâ€™ by Taylor Swift

Among the many ghosts of Taylor Swiftâ€™s pre-pop past is a Christmas album that will hopefully not get re-recorded by the artist a la Red and Fearless. None of the tracks from The Taylor Swift Holiday Collection hold a candle to â€™tis the damn season,â€™ from the post-folklore and post-capitilisation album evermore. In full storyteller mode, it finds the singer staying at her parents house for the holidays, getting nostalgic for the small-town sights and a familiar touch. Can you belt it out like â€˜jingle bell rock?â€™ Nah. But it might inspire you to call your high-school crush for a stroll when youâ€™re bored.

Advertising

53. â€˜Christmas Will Really Be Christmasâ€™ by Lou Rawls

The great Lou Rawlsâ€™s plea for equality and peace over the holidays has a certain urgency thanks to its soulful horns and the fact that his holiday wish remains just thatâ€¦ a wish. Give Lou a spin, then seek out Austin soul group Black Pumas take: an organ-heavy reworking of Rawls's overlooked classic of downbeat optimism.

54. â€˜Hey Sis, It's Christmasâ€™ by RuPaul

This highlight from RuPaulâ€™s Christmas album isnâ€™t a spangly dance banger, but a bone-shaking festive bop with an old-school hip hop flavour. Itâ€™s also completely infectious, especially when Ru purrs: â€˜Hey sis, it's Christmas / You can cross me off of your wish list.â€™ Who could resist her?

Advertising

55. â€˜I Wish It Was Christmas Todayâ€™ by Julian Casablancas

â€˜I Wish It Was Christmas Todayâ€™ was actually a â€˜Saturday Night Liveâ€™ ditty written by Jimmy Fallon and Horatio Sanz back in 2000, and a staple on the long-running US comedy show throughout the â€˜00s. But it will now forever be defined by this tremendous version by Strokes frontman Julian Casablancas, which perfectly melds the songâ€™s bratty demand for Christmas, now, with his day jobâ€™s raw, insouciant new wave. If it has had a slightly less convoluted origin you have to think it would be a little better known. But really, it stands as the last great indie Christmas song.

Andrzej Lukowski

Theatre & Dance Editor, UK

56. â€˜Wonderful Christmas Timeâ€™ by Diana Ross

Ross's rendition of Macca's festive favourite is definitely a Supreme cover version â€” drenched in strings and sleigh bells, it sounds a little more wholesome and old-timey than the trippy original, especially when you factor in her still-magical Soprano. It's one to roast chestnuts to, for sure.

Advertising

57. â€˜Merry Christmas (I Donâ€™t Want To Fight Tonight)â€™ by The Ramones

Joey Ramoneâ€™s plea to his lover to put their scrapping aside for the holidays is undoubtedly the punk Christmas anthem. Beneath its acquiescent lyrics, mind, is a typically fiery Ramones riff thatâ€™s more likely to fuel high tensions rather than ease them around a warring Christmas dinner table.

58. â€˜Dominick the Donkeyâ€™ By Lou Monte

Novelty songwriter Lou Monte â€“ with a rumoured assist from the Gambino crime family â€“ was looking for a Rudolph-level hit with this tale about a donkey enlisted by Santa to climb the hills of Italy. Thatâ€¦ didnâ€™t happen. But in crafting a song specifically for Italian Americans â€“ and in legendary lines like â€˜ A pair of shoes for Louie and a dress for Josephine / The label on the inside says they're made in Brook-a-leenâ€™ â€“ he entered the obscure novelty song hall of fame. A karaoke banger for those who truly bang.

Advertising

59. â€˜Christmas Vacationâ€™ by Mavis Staples

Yes, this is the theme to the Chevy Chase classic of the same name, but even the most ardent fans seldom realize that soul icon Mavis Staples is the one crooning out the somewhat corny â€˜Hip, hip hooray, for Christmas vacation.â€™ That this isnâ€™t a staple (sorry) is absolutely shocking, given the pedigree behind the mic, the status of the film and the quality of the song itself.

60. â€˜Twelve Days of Christmasâ€™ by Bob and Doug McKenzie

Dave Thomas and Rick Moranisâ€™s contribution to the Christmas canon is a riff on the holiday classic performed as their well-lubricated alter egos Bob & Doug McKenzie. The first coup? Replacing a partridge in a pear tree with an off-time â€˜a beer.â€™ Itâ€™s a boozy, rambling blast from the Strange Brew stars.
